title: Before 1 September 2022, will the government of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) officially announce a change to its weekend?
preds:
Bringing my probability down after hearing this podcast with the owner of a recruitment agency in Dubai
https://www.thenationalnews.com/business/money/2021/08/24/is-a-four-day-working-week-possible-in-the-uae-pocketful-of-dirhams/

The UAE is officially a Muslim country and Friday is the holy day of the week, like Sunday is for Christians. Therefore, it is highly unlikely (95-99%) that the government shifts the weekend to Saturday-Sunday by 2022. Doing such a move could backlash politically, also from other Muslim countries.  On the other side, recently the government has been more flexible on Islamic rules by decriminalising the consumption of alcohol and cohabitation. This summer Dubai also allowed restaurants to stay open during Ramadan. And shifting the weekend would allow the country to be more in sync with Western weekends.  If the government announces a change to the weekend, it will most likely be a half-day on Friday, which is not that convenient. Would people have 2 half days and 1 full day off work? Doesn't sound like an amazing sell to the people.
Too much resistance from religious conservatives within own and neighbouring countries

I found this article dated to 2003, which discusses should the UAE opt for "Friday-Saturday" as the weekend or not?
https://gulfnews.com/uae/two-day-weekend-which-day-to-club-with-friday-1.362545 "In May 2006, the UAE changed its weekends from Thursday-Friday to Friday-Saturday, which went into effect in September of that year."
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1927906/offbeat However, the executive director of WAM - Emirates News Agency, also known as WAM, is the official news agency of the United Arab Emirates. - called any discussion with regard to changes to the weekend policy in the government as "fake".  => At this moment I don't think such change would be deemed plausible in the time period of 1 year from now.  I don't think half-day Friday would be plausible as well, as the midday prayer - perhaps the main activity and reason for importance of Friday - would interfere.  I'm curious to see if they go for 4-day workweek, kinda like Iceland?!
Half-day on Friday seems feasible but it is still unlikely.
